content.div:
You'd be forgiven for thinking actor Nick Offerman and his Parks and Recreation character, Ron Swanson, are one and the same. They're both manly, mustachioed men who love the outdoors. They both play a mean saxophone. And they both have a thing for Megan Mullally.

In fact, during a recent call with reporters to promote the upcoming season of the NBC sitcom, Offerman offered up a constant stream of sound bites that seemed like they were lifted directly from his fictional alter-ego's mouth. Here's just a sampling of the actor's Swanson-esque observations:

• On the emasculation of the modern man:

"I can legitimately say that I insist on no shaving or waxing. I think that the emasculation of the modern man in popular culture is something that has weakened our society considerably. I don't know why a heroic male these days has to have a hairless torso. You know, I grew up admiring Joe Don Baker swinging a baseball bat and walking tall; he was a hairy son of a bitch. And to me, that's a hero. You know, I'm a big fan of your Brad Pitts and your Jude Laws, but I'd like to see a little hair on their chests, if they're going to be beating somebody up."

• On posing nude with real-life wife Mullally in New York Magazine:

"To prepare for that photo shoot, we took a three-week tour of Europe, where I sampled the sausages of five nations, ending with a 16-inch-long bratwurst in the Town Square of Prague, a mere 18 hours before that photo shoot. And if you look closely in the picture, you can make out a bulge that I think is representative of that particular pork sausage."

• On why audiences are responding to him:

"I usually assume it's my musk that attracts people. I keep the dander to a minimum and I keep it clean, but I use just a little bit of hibiscus oil behind each shoulder."

It's here that Parks co-creator and executive producer, Mike Schur, who's also on the call, interjects. "I just want to make it clear for anybody who's never spoken with Nick Offerman before, this is really how he talks. He's not doing a bit. This is actually the way that he talks in normal conversation."

It's no wonder Schur and the Parks writers have incorporated many of Offerman's real-life mannerisms and hobbies into the script. Ron Swanson's jazz-loving alter-ego, Duke Silver, came about when the writers realized the actor could play the saxophone. Like his character, Offerman is into woodworking and even builds his own canoes. (He released an instructional DVD in 2008 entitled Canoe Building with Nick Offerman.) Schur hints that the actor's "home repair skills" will make an appearance in a future episode. But there's one aspect of Offerman's life the writers have yet to incorporate into the show.

"I have a penchant for the ballet, and I've been pitching the fellows for the whole time we've been in production for a Ron Swan Lake episode," admits Offerman. "I haven't heard of anything coming down the pike just yet, though."

Not that his character doesn't already have enough to deal with this season. On last year's finale, we got a glimpse of Ron Swanson's first ex-wife, Tammy One, a woman so hideous, she made his second wife, the sexually depraved Tammy Two (played by Mullally), flee in fear. In the season premiere, the audience gets a closer look at Tammy One (played by Patricia Clarkson) and the second episode also introduces us to Ron's mother, who's also named - you guessed it - Tammy.

"I think what the audience will be surprised to learn is that Tammy Two may turn out to be the most kitten-like, timid women of the Tammys," teases Offerman. "I am about as giggly as a schoolgirl to have landed in a position where I'm portraying a man who has made love to both Megan Mullally and Patricia Clarkson. That is a consummation devoutly to be wished."

Not only are Ron's ex-wives vastly different, but so is his behaviour around them. While Tammy Two turns him into a hedonistic, sexual maniac, Tammy One's presence reduces Ron to a simpering, neutered wimp.

"She is very different from Tammy Two's character," reveals Schur. "The relationship she has with Ron is not a sort of animal attraction, pure and simple, that we've seen before. They have a much different, more complicated, more kind of rich backstory that we get into and delve into."

Beyond getting the chance to explore a different side of his character, Offerman says he was thrilled to get the chance to work with Clarkson.

"I've been such a huge fan of hers for many years, and it's nothing short of a dream come true that I got to actually work in scenes with her," he says. "Not only is she gorgeous and an incredible actress, but she is insanely hilarious, to boot. I think everybody on set was just bowled over with how funny she was on the show."

While Clarkson is only scheduled to appear in the first two episode of the new season, Ron will continue to have a lot on his plate this season. Schur hinted he'll become a Scout leader, his interaction with Tom will increase, and there will be "some kind of romance story with Ron down the line."

Whatever's in store for Ron, Offerman is looking forward to it.

"Every time I'm handed a new script, I feel like a largemouth bass at a nightcrawler convention," he gushes.

Ron Swanson couldn't have said it better.

Parks and Recreation returns Sept. 22 at 8:30 ET/PT on NBC and Citytv.

entry.title: Modern Family Cleans Up At Emmys

link.Abstract: In the comedy awards, Modern Family won a total of five awards. The major drama acting awards went instead to Kyle Chandler for Friday Night Lights, and Julianna Margulies for The Good Wife.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: Actor Ty Burrell and actress Julie Bowen of Modern Family pose in the press room after winning outstanding supporting actor and actress in a comedy series 2011 during the 63rd Annual Primetime Emmy Awards on September 18, 2011 in Los Angeles, California.
link.title: Actor Ty Burrell and actress Julie Bowen of Modern Family pose in the press room after winning outstanding supporting actor and actress in a comedy series 2011 during the 63rd Annual Primetime Emmy Awards on September 18, 2011 in Los Angeles, California.

link.Abstract: The stars of the small screen shone at the 2011 Emmy Awards. Rate their red carpet styles.
link.title: Photos: Rate the Emmy Fashions

link.Abstract: From the surprising wins to the awkward speeches, relive all the shocks, jokes, blunders and upsets at the 2011 Emmy Awards. (by Jon Dekel/Dose.ca)
link.title: Photos: Best and Worst Emmy Moments

link.Abstract: They're the stars of two of TV's most celebrated shows, 30 Rock and Mad Men. But Alec Baldwin and January Jones weren't at the Emmy Awards Sunday night. Jones was home with her new baby; Baldwin was in New York, hosting Tony Bennett's birthday party.
link.title: Why Weren't Alec Baldwin and January Jones at the Emmys?
